content.question: The diagrams above show the ultraviolet absorption spectra for two compounds. Diagram 1 is the absorption spectrum of pure acetone, a solvent used when preparing solutions for an experiment. Diagram 2 is the absorption spectrum of the solute for which the absorbance needs to be measured to determine its concentration. When the student reads the absorbance of the solution at <math alttext="280 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>280</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the result is too high. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the error in the measured absorbance?

choices.label: The student added too little solute to the acetone before measuring its absorbance.
The student rinsed the cuvette with the solution before filling the cuvette with the solution.
The student forgot to calibrate the spectrophotometer first by using a cuvette containing only acetone.

The wavelength setting was accidentally changed from <math alttext="280 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>280</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="300 nanometers" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>300</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>nm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> before the student made the measurement.

content.answer: The student forgot to calibrate the spectrophotometer first by using a cuvette containing only acetone.

skill.text: 2.E: Identify or describe potential sources of experimental error.
